results.title: Just one kid
results.brief_description: An autobiographical look at the life of a Jewish boy growing up in London during the 1930’s providing a nostalgic impression of the Jewish community in London’s East End at that time. Highlights cultural traditions, continuity and change and the social conditions in the 30’s.

results.title: Just managing
results.creator_credit: Bruce Belsham, Glyn Patric and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
On a world scale, Australian managers rank 23rd for quality. It is estimated that 85% of Australia’s corporate problems are the fault of senior management, who have a basic lack of understanding of what is required to be competitive in today’s market. This program looks at examples of good and bad management in Australia, including AWA, Holden and Mitsubishi and at modern management theories such as Total Quality Management, as developed by W. Edwards Deming and Just-in-time systems which are aimed at optimising supplies. Illustrated by brief excerpts from John Cleese’s management video.

results.title: Just like you
results.creator_credit: Eugene Osborne Smith and Stephen Bosustow Productions
results.brief_description: Society is made up of all sorts of people who share common hopes and dreams. Each person should be able to advance according to ability. However, the difference between people create conflicts and barriers that hinder the success of some. A montage of photographs accompanied by the poem ‘Just Like You’ presents these concepts.

results.title: Just like you
results.creator_credit: Fran Haarsma, Ideas That Work and Fran Haarsma Productions
results.brief_description: Just like you is a comprehensive guide for people who are unsure of how to act around people with disabilities. The program answers questions such as, can you say “look” to a person who is blind? Do you offer to push someone in a wheelchair? Presented by people with disabilities, we are shown the preferred etiquette that can make interaction easier for both parties.

results.title: Just like other kids: Ramona Marsh
results.creator_credit: Elisabeth Knight, James Ricketson and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Fair Go”.
One of a 7 part series which examines the impact of mental and physical disability on individual Australians and their families. They demonstrate the practical implications of coping with a disability in daily life at home, in the work place, at school and in the community. Presented from the viewpoint of the disabled person. This program is about 15 year old Ramona Marsh who is partially sighted, a condition she inherited from her mother. Suitable for secondary and tertiary levels.

results.creator_credit: Tasmanian Film Corporation and Don Anderson
results.brief_description: Instructs on safe methods of handling pesticides, their application and storage. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Just for me
results.creator_credit: Dee Simpson, ONF | NFB and Lois Tupper
results.brief_description: Just for Me documents three women’s experiences with fitness and sport: that of a homemaker with children, an office worker who has just moved to the city, and a married school teacher. The film looks at the women before they participate in a sport, as well as during and after the experience.

results.title: Just for dad
results.brief_description: My Dad means a lot to me. He works in Western Australia now, so I don’t get to see him as much as I used to. This story is a tribute to my Dad.

results.title: Just do it
results.creator_credit: La Verite Films, Kim Snow, Jenny Livingston and Sarah Hatherley
results.brief_description: Two thirty-something women, Alice, an aspiring filmmaker, and Sandy, a student with a messy love life, meet regularly to walk around the domain. As they walk they talk about the state of their lives, yet, due especially to Sandy’s self-obsession and insensitivity, their conversations are less dialogues than therapeutic monologues. The tables are turned when Sandy’s unsympathetic response to her friend’s creative struggles, and her dismissive remark to ‘just do it’ have an unexpected outcome. Cast: Alison Whyte, Alice Garner.
